newsitem.title: CANADA: TENNIS-SELES WINS 6-0 6-0 TO REACH CANADIAN OPEN SEMIS.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-SELES WINS 6-0 6-0 TO REACH CANADIAN OPEN SEMIS.

text.p: Top-seeded Monica Seles outclassed unseeded qualifier Rita Grande of Italy 6-0 6-0 Friday in the quarter-finals of the $926,250 Canadian Open.
"I hit some great shots that even surprised myself," the third-ranked Seles said after her 42-minute win over the 69th-ranked Grande.

Seles will now play seventh-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain in Saturday's afternoon semifinal. Martinez advanced with her sixth consecutive win over fourth-seeded Lindsay Davenport, beating the American 6-4 4-6 6-2. The evening semifinal will match fifth-seeded Anke Huber of Germany and 10th-seeded American Mary Joe Fernandez. Huber edged third-seeded Amanda Coetzer of South Africa 2-6 6-1 6-4 while Fernandez prevailed 6-2 6-7 (3-7) 6-4 over unseeded Magdalena Maleeva of Bulgaria.
"I think she had a big win yesterday (over sixth-seeded Mary Pierce of France)," Seles said about Grande, "and it's always hard to come back and play after that."
Grande saw the humour in the onesided match, smiling and throwing up her hands to show how futile things were against an on-form Seles.
Would Seles ever give a player a game when she is winning by such a onesided margin?

"I just take it point by point," she answered. "I forget where I was three or four weeks ago but I was winning 6-0 4-0 and I lost a game and the crowd started to clap because they thought I was being nice and giving a game. But I'd never give a game and I don't expect anyone to give me a game in that situation."
"She's very frustrating for me to play," Davenport said about her sixth straight loss to the ninth-ranked Martinez. "She puts a lot of topspin on her forehand and a lot of slice on her backhand."

The match was interrupted by heavy downpours for over four hours with Davenport leading 5-4 in the second set. "In the third set, I was a lot more impatient and I made a lot of unforced errors," the fifth-ranked Davenport said.
"But the last couple of times I got killed (6-1 6-3 and 6-2 6-3) by her so at least I played the right way, aggressively. Maybe the next time it'll be different."
"Lindsay played unbelievable in the second set," Martinez said. "When she hits winners there's not much you can do. But after that I tried to be more aggressive."

Seles and Martinez have played 12 times, and not once has a match gone three sets. The 23-year-old Seles won the first 11 with Martinez breaking the ice with a 7-6 6-4 victory in Palo Alto, California, three weeks ago.
"I'm very confident now and I feel I'm at my best," Martinez said.

The 25-year-old Spaniard has been working with a new athletic trainer since March and has lost a considerable amount of weight. She would not reveal the amount but did say she now weighs 135 pounds (61 kg).
"When you're weight is up, you don't go to the scales very often," she said with a smile. "Now, I'm going every day."
The eighth-ranked Huber and the sixth-ranked Coetzer waged tough baseline battle on Court Number One after it was relocated from centre court by the rain.

"I was impatient in the first set, and very disappointed in myself," Huber said. "It was hard to win a point from the baseline against Amanda because she hits with a lot of topspin, and it was very humid and the balls really fluffed up. I had to be patient and be willing to hit 20 balls every rally."
